title: Victorian Opposition calls for action on second residence allowance - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
Victorian Opposition calls for action on second residence allowance Posted February 25, 2017 11:30:52 Map: Ocean Grove 3226 
Premier Daniel Andrews must take action after revelations the Deputy Speaker had made a claim under the second residence allowance which is meant for country MPs, the Victorian Opposition says. 
Deputy Speaker Don Nardella, who represents the seat of Melton, in Melbourne's north-west, has been living over 90 kilometres away at Ocean Grove on the Bellarine Peninsula and claiming the allowance. 
Under parliamentary rules, politicians are entitled to the "second residence" allowance if their home base is at least 80km from Melbourne's CBD and they keep a second property in the city. 
It comes after Speaker Telmo Languiller promised to repay $37,678 he claimed under the allowance for living in Queenscliff, more than 80 kilometres from Melbourne. 
Mr Languiller told Parliament he moved to Queenscliff for complex personal reasons. 
Opposition MP Tim Smith said while claiming the allowance was not illegal, it was not within the spirit of the entitlement. 
"It's not meant for city MPs who've decided they're going to go into semi-retirement and move to the seaside, far away from their electorate," he said. 
"I mean who do these people think they are? Middle European royalty or something?" 
Confirming Mr Nardella had also claimed the allowance, a government spokesperson said the matter had been referred to the Audit Committee of Parliament and that the Premier urged the committee to provide recommendations on the use of the entitlement "as soon as possible." 
On Friday Premier Daniel Andrews defended Mr Languiller, saying he had not made any excuses and would repay the money. 
Mr Andrews said it was "self-evident" the entitlement was designed to cover expenses for country MPs, not city MPs living in regional areas. 
Mr Smith said the allowance claimed by Mr Nardella should be repaid. 
"No-one forced Don Nardella to move to Ocean Grove and frankly, he represents Melton," he said. 
"We, in the Liberal Party, sign a statutory declaration saying that we'll live in our electorate. 
"The Labor Party should do the same. This idea that people live miles from their electorate shows the contempt they hold for the people they're trying to represent." 
Mr Andrews repeatedly spoke out about the misuse of entitlements as Opposition leader in 2014, at the height of a political crisis triggered by former balance-of-power Independent MP Geoff Shaw. 
In June 2014, Mr Andrews sought to have the former Frankston MP expelled for misusing his parliamentary car and fuel card. 
But the Premier insisted there was a "very, very big difference" between Mr Shaw's case and Mr Languiller's claim.
